title: Tech Moves: Seattle Chamber CEO joins Washington Roundtable; Meta and F5 leaders depart
description: In Pacific Northwest tech moves, leaders at Meta and F5 depart for unknown new roles while Seattle Chamber's CEO leaves for Washington Roundtable.
content:
— Rachel Smith, president and CEO of the Seattle Metro Chamber, is leaving her role at the business advocacy organization to become president of the Washington Roundtable.

Smith has led the chamber since 2021, guiding it through the COVID recovery, supporting BIPOC-owned businesses, working on Sound Transit expansion and other issues.

Over her career, Smith has worked in numerous Seattle-area civic roles including leadership in King County and City of Seattle government offices. She will continue engaging with the Seattle Metro Chamber in her new role at Washington Roundtable, which is a nonprofit that works to influence public policy and is composed of senior executives from major companies in the state.

Gabriella Buono, the chamber’s chief impact officer, will serve as interim president and CEO while the board of trustees seeks a permanent leader.

— Michael Atalla is leaving F5 after nearly four years, resigning from the role of senior vice president and head of worldwide marketing. Atalla said it was “hard to capture” what his time has meant at the Seattle-based security and application delivery giant.

“I’ve had the privilege of working with some of the smartest, kindest, most relentlessly curious people in the business — and I don’t take that for granted,” he said on LinkedIn.

Atalla’s career includes nearly 14 years at Microsoft, ending in 2016 as a director with the Office 365 group. He also co-founded The MJJM Group, which advises business clients on product growth and supports fundraising efforts. Atalla has not disclosed his next step.

— Generative AI principal engineer Hitesh Jain is leaving Meta. Jain has been with the company for more than 13 years, most recently working to personalize AI chatbots so they are “helpful and engaging,” he said in his LinkedIn profile.

In announcing his departure, Jain said he joined the Meta straight out of the Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee in India. “Moving halfway across the world to the U.S. was an unexpected leap — but one of the best decisions of my life,” he added. “What started as just a job quickly became a defining chapter of my journey. Over the years, I had the privilege of working from Seattle, [Menlo Park, Calif.], and Dublin.”

Tech companies are scrambling to hire top AI talent, with Meta reportedly offering salaries of $100 million per year. Jain did not name his next role, saying, “It’s the start of a new chapter for me. Stay tuned for what’s next.”

— Adriana Gil Miner stepped down from her role as chief marketing and strategy officer at Iterable. Miner held the post for more than three years, and said on LinkedIn that she loved the chance to “market to marketers” at the San Francisco-based B2B company.

“Few marketers get the opportunity to meet the people behind the brands you love and use every day,” Miner said on LinkedIn.

Before joining Iterable, Miner held leadership roles at multiple Seattle-area companies, serving as senior vice president of marketing for Tableau Software and CMO of both Qumulo and Artefact. She did not share her next move.

— Former WatchGuard Technologies CEO Prakash Panjwani joined the board of directors for Starfire Sports. The organization provides coding classes, drone summer camps, and other free, after-school sports programming for underprivileged kids in South Seattle.

“I strongly believe that we have a tremendous opportunity to influence our youth in their early years by offering them exposure to everything from sports to STEM so that they are better prepared to contribute positively to society,” Panjwani said in a statement.

— Seattle industrial analytics company Seeq named Anton Chilton to its board of directors. Chilton was with manufacturing and supply chain solutions company QAD for more than two decades, rising to the role of CEO. Seeq uses AI, analytics, and monitoring to data that helps industrial businesses optimize their operations.
summary: Rachel Smith, president and CEO of the Seattle Metro Chamber, is leaving her position to become president of the Washington Roundtable. She has led the chamber since 2021 and will continue working with it in her new role. Gabrielle Buono, the chamber’s chief impact officer, will temporarily serve as interim president. Michael Atalla is leaving F5 after nearly four years, resigning from his position as senior vice president and head of worldwide marketing. Hitesh Jain is also leaving Meta, where he has been working for over 13 years working to personalize AI chatbots so they are helpful and engaging. Other notable tech moves include the resignation of Adriana Gil Miner from her position as chief marketing and strategy officer at Iterable.
shortSummary: Despite Rachel Smith's leadership and Hitesh Jain's departure from F5, Rachel Smith joins the Washington Roundtable, while Adriana Gil Miner and Prakash Panjwani leave F5.

A few weeks ago, I closed out my chapter as Iterable’s CMO. I leave with a full ❤️ and a sharper lens on what it really takes to win in today’s B2B markets. As an advocate for the company, I’m excited to stay connected and help recruit the next great CMO to lead Iterable to new heights! I’m incredibly proud of what we’ve built at Iterable over the last 3.5 years—and I’m thankful to Andrew Boni, Jeffrey Samuels, Stephanie Buscemi for the opportunity to help shape the future of marketing. I am especially grateful to the Iterable marketing team—you’re just a dream! Katie Pope, Mike Braund, Heather Blank, Lauren Kopulsky, Amanda Dailey, and Gray Hardell: Thank you for the opportunity to lead you, for all your feedback, for the discussions, and for the gusto in innovating and raising the bar. Together, we’ve helped Iterable grow in one of the wildest environments. We’ve rebranded, repositioned, magnificently expanded our community programs, broadened our product mix and SKUs, attracted and helped win amazing new customers, elevated our Activate program to be a Tier 1 experience (on a neutral budget!), transformed our operations with AI, and raised the bar for B2B marketing. My biggest joy —> I’ve LOVED marketing to marketers (🍽️ serving food to chefs!), and I’m so grateful to our customers, partners, and this powerhouse team. Few marketers get the opportunity to meet the people behind the brands you love and use every day. And I’ve known from the get-go how special it is to have that window into such iconic brands like LaserAway, Grammarly, REI, Bloomberg, Strava, Priceline, Volvo, Nando's, Fabletics, Cinemark, and so many more! I’ll be a lifelong supporter of Iterable and am excited for what’s next—for the team, our new CEO Sam Allen, and the next CMO (this is an incredible seat to step into!) My martech CMO gig may be up, but I’m still a marketer, and the mission remains: Let’s keep building the future of marketing where we bring joy to customers, one moment at a time! 💥 More on my next adventure soon—but for now, I’m enjoying the beautiful Seattle summer with my brother and nieces visiting from Spain, and taking time to breathe, reflect, and feel gratitude for every phase of life. Here are a few of my favorite moments over the last few years—impossible to pick among so many great memories. 🥰
-
+15
Adriana Gil Miner I am going to miss you so much! You have been such an incredible leader and have personally helped me in my career, to which I am thankful and forever in your dept. 💕
You are THE BEST Adri, will sincerely miss your sunshine and your incredibly smart ideas to help us be better partners and to grow our business. You’ve developed an amazing team and are leaving behind a very strong legacy at Iterable. I’ve definitely learned more than just dance moves from you and I’m hopeful our paths will cross again in the future.
Adriana Gil Miner - what a run! Your passion and authenticity around marketing to marketers was palpable, and you helped build such an incredible community. It was so great to work with you and your amazing team. Cheers to you and to what’s next 🥂
What an amazing impact you had on so many people in our community! Thank you for raising the bar and for all your support and friendship over the years. So excited for you! 👏👏👏
You’re truly the best! It’s been such a joy and honor working alongside you, watching you continually raise the bar for our team. I’m so excited to see all the amazing things you’ll accomplish in your next adventure!
Congrats to you and your next epic chapter!
One of the best! Thank you Adriana Gil Miner for helping me be a better marketer, person, and father. Forever grateful to get to see you do what you do.
Congrats Adri!! It had been amazing to watch how you and your team have elevated the Iterable brand in the last few years. The conferences and go-to-market motions your team put together have been truly world-class. Congrats on a great run and cannot wait to hear what you will do next.
👋 Partner Revenue Leader | Connecter & Relationship Builder | Ex-Salesforce | Ex-Drift | Process Specialist | Spreading "CHARMONY" throughout the Ecosystem

Some news: I’ll be wrapping up my time at F5. It’s hard to capture what the last four years have meant. I’ve had the privilege of working with some of the smartest, kindest, most relentlessly curious people in the business—and I don’t take that for granted. To everyone who put on an event, built a campaign plan, squinted at demand analytics, debated strategy, provided me a sounding board, or just looked out the window at that beautiful view of The Puget Sound from the F5 Tower —thank you. You made the work matter. When we leave a building we don't need to leave the people. F5'ers, I hope you agree. More to come on what’s next. For now, just gratitude. Cristin McClellan Sarah Woods Kristen Grant Rob Gruening Erin J. Melinda H. Joel Ertsgaard Dawn Perry Alison Cable Kelly Campbell Farrell, SPHR Kuna Nallappan Gimena Martínez Llorente Kate W. Nicole Steele Bobby Shely JM Caballero Clarissa Konatsu Erica Ginsburg Amy Yerrington Chandni Dighe, MS MBA PCM Pascale Royal Marcus Sorour Olga Royenko Jade Meara Lisa Goh Kristine Olson and many, many more.
Congratulations on your massive impact at F5. I am fortunate to have been part of your very first major project there. I look forward to seeing what's next for you.
Congrats on tremendous impact there Michael!!
Congratulations Michael and all the best for the future! It has been great working with you at F5 😀
You will be missed my friend! Thank you for your unwavering support of our partners and our channel team.
Hi Michael best of luck on your next venture and thank you for the great support of APCJ 🙏
Congratulations on a great run at F5, Atalla!
It was a pleasure working with you, Michael. Best of luck!
Well boss, what can I say? I will start with a heartfelt THANK YOU for all the support, guidance, mentoring and partnership you have shown me in abundance…. Thank you for being the longest standing manager I’ve had at F5, by a long way!! Thank you for affording me opportunities to grow, trusting me to take on more, to expand my skills and to become an infinitely better leader under your tutelage. I will miss our chats, our laughs, our philosophy sessions where many a challenge was unpacked and examined for insights and learnings, and for being a firm hand on our ship’s metaphorical rudder when we hit the occasional turbulent patch of water. A true skipper in every respect - I will miss you but wish you a world of luck and success in your new role as CMO of a new company and new team - they have a great ride ahead!! Enjoy!!
Sad to see you leaving Michael Atalla . Thanks for all the great things you’ve accomplished at F5. All the best in your new adventure.

5dThank you for your support and guidance. All the best to your next move.

Leaving Meta 💙 Hi LinkedIn, after 13 incredible years, I’ve decided to move on from Meta. I joined Meta (then Facebook) straight out of IIT Roorkee in India. Moving halfway across the world to the U.S. was an unexpected leap — but one of the best decisions of my life. What started as just a job quickly became a defining chapter of my journey. Over the years, I had the privilege of working from Seattle, MPK, and Dublin. Along the way, I learned what it truly means to build reliable, intelligent, and safe software at scale. More importantly, I found mentors, collaborators, and lifelong friends. Meta has been more than a workplace — it’s where I grew up, stumbled, learned, and celebrated wins both big and small. I’ll carry the memories, lessons, and friendships with me wherever I go. To everyone I’ve worked with over the years: thank you for trusting me, challenging me, and shaping the person I’ve become. It’s the start of a new chapter for me. Stay tuned for what’s next. 🚀
Wow! Bittersweet but excited for your next adventure!
Whatever you do, you will do great!! Can’t wait to know what’s next 🎉🎉🎉
wow!
Looking forward for an amazing update ! 🥳
What a run! It's been great working together and I look forward to seeing what you choose to do next. Best of luck!
All the best for future endeavors!
Good luck on your next endeavor! I am sure you'll succeed
Best wishes for future endeavors!
All the best for exciting future!!
Founder @ PwrOn | Portable Power Network

“I'm fan of Michael. He stepped in to my early-stage start-up and helped me take my vision to reality in terms of designing the product vision, defining the requirements, and then helping me execute it with a development partner. Beyond the technical vision and execution, Michael became a sparring partner for all parts of my business - technical, go-to-market, even how we position the company for investment. I'm grateful to have someone that gets it so quickly and then can dive in to make things happen. He brings so much more than a typical adviser. A true partner for any startup founder/CEO.”

Microsoft Demos

See projectFaced with the advent of SaaS solutions, I conceived of a first-of-its-kind cloud services demo platform at Microsoft. Delivering this platform involved building a dedicated product team within my marketing organization to architect, develop, and maintain this always on environment. The product addressed the challenge of providing sales organizations within Microsoft and in the Microsoft partner community an easy way to spin up a fully formed demo environment based on the latest technologies…
Faced with the advent of SaaS solutions, I conceived of a first-of-its-kind cloud services demo platform at Microsoft. Delivering this platform involved building a dedicated product team within my marketing organization to architect, develop, and maintain this always on environment. The product addressed the challenge of providing sales organizations within Microsoft and in the Microsoft partner community an easy way to spin up a fully formed demo environment based on the latest technologies. My team delivered carefully curated content packs which, when orchestrated, generated an Office 365 environment which looked like an actively running business, with email, documents, libraries, meetings scheduled, etc. all by vertical and geography. A seller could, on any one day, spin up an entire demo ecosystem, customized with company name and industry focus, with the click of a button and just as easily reset that environment for the next demo. Detailed content plans and extensive demo guides made this an incredibly popular tool across the Microsoft ecosystem. Developed initially as a demo environment for Microsoft Exchange Online, our team expanded its mission to cover the entire Office 365 environment and then beyond that to encompass Dynamics and System Center components. The result of this project was a durable and highly functional tool that became fundamental to the way Microsoft and its partners sell to commercial customers.
-
Microsoft Exchange Conference
-
See projectAs the Microsoft Exchange business shifted from Server to Service (SaaS), our tight partnership with the Exchange Administrator community, upon which much of our success was anchored, was at risk. This community viewed SaaS, at the time, as technology that would reduce their control, put their companies at risk, and put them out of a job. To reinvigorate our relationship with this critical technical community and put ourselves on footing to leverage the community to not only preserve our Server…
As the Microsoft Exchange business shifted from Server to Service (SaaS), our tight partnership with the Exchange Administrator community, upon which much of our success was anchored, was at risk. This community viewed SaaS, at the time, as technology that would reduce their control, put their companies at risk, and put them out of a job. To reinvigorate our relationship with this critical technical community and put ourselves on footing to leverage the community to not only preserve our Server business but grow our SaaS business, I conceived of, led the planning for, and execution of the Microsoft Exchange Conference, returning the event to the Microsoft after being suspended 10 years earlier. This event met with critical success and drove a wave of positive sentiment. By taking a community-centric focus and helping to establish that it was this community that would lead the transition to the cloud, rather than Microsoft, we built meaningful credibility which translated into advocacy from influential and outspoken IT leaders and built momentum with customers in the midst of the cloud migration decision making process. Establishing a social media movement (leveraging hashtag #iammec) and connecting the event theme and community identity to that social media movement produced a tightly integrated marketing plan that went well beyond the physical event space and gave the community and the Exchange product team a shared context upon which we successfully rebuilt our advocacy network and formed the basis of our continued dominance in this segment despite a growing threat from Google and other smaller cloud-only vendors.

Michael Atalla resigns as senior vice president and head of worldwide marketing at F5 after nearly four years. Hitesh Jain, a generative AI principal engineer, leaves Meta after 13 years, while Adriana Gil Miner departs Iterable as chief marketing and strategy officer. Additionally, former WatchGuard CEO Prakash Panjwani joins the board of Starfire Sports, and Anton Chilton joins the board of Seeq, a Seattle industrial analytics company.
